Dutch.Introduction: The Dutch East India Company (Dutch: Vereenigde Oostindische Compagnie, often known as VOC) was a chartered company which issued a considerable series of coinage in bronze, silver and gold for its territories in the Far East between 1602 and 1799.

Coin.Title: 1 duit, 1737
Coin.Obverse: Crown over shield containing two lions.
Coin.Reverse:
VOC monogram in middle, mintmark (rosette) at top between flowers, date below.
Lettering: VOC 1737
Translation: VOC (Vereenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie) : United East India Company

Coin.Title: 1 duit, 1790
Coin.Obverse: Crowned Utrecht arms with lion supporters.
Coin.Reverse:
VOC monogram in middle, mintmark (Star) at top , date below.
Lettering: VOC 1790
Translation: VOC (Vereenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie) : United East India Company

Coin.Title: 1 duit, 1794
Coin.Obverse: Coat of Arms of Zeeland, Netherlands. Dutch lion in sea on shield with crown.
Coin.Reverse:
VOC monogram in middle, castle at top between stars, date below.
Lettering: VOC 1794
Translation: VOC (Vereenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie) : United East India Company
